source.citation: Kizha, A.R. et al. 2020. Comparing hot and cold loading in an integrated biomass recovery operation. Forests 11(385).
notes: Thunderbird 840W loader (1980s) supporting a Madill cable yarder in northern California biomass + sawlog operations (April 2015).
Hot loading: sawlogs and biomass handled concurrently at the landing; cold loading: biomass handled later with roll-off trucks/containers.

costing.utilisation_reference: Machine rates calculated for 2000 SMH/year, 10% interest, 3% insurance (company data).

scenarios.description: Loader clears sawlogs and biomass concurrently; biomass placed in detached roll-off bins while yarder cycles continue.
scenarios.bottleneck: Yarder rigging/hang-ups and log-truck batches forced the loader to idle; OSHA crew-in-zone rules compounded the delay.
notes: Loader movement between multiple sawlog decks counted as productive time; delay tracked separately.
Rigging new corridors averaged 49 minutes, idling loader/chaser.
Roll-off trucks occasionally waited 10â€“15 minutes to enter landing during peak sawlog loading.

scenarios.description: Biomass removed after sawlog machines left; loader fills roll-off containers while a single truck hauls bins to centralized landing.
scenarios.bottleneck: Roll-off truck supply (one truck serving 11 bins with ~2 h round trip, 15 min turnaround delays).
notes: Loader typically filled three bins within 30 minutes then idled for incoming empties.
Landing space had to accommodate all biomass prior to haul; sawlog equipment already demobbed.
Cold loading reduced sawlog congestion but magnified loader delays when truck fleet was undersized.
